title-group.article-title: A micromechanical model of the evolution of stress and strain fields in ultrafine-grained metal structures under tension

contrib-group.aff: Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Parma, Parma, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Luca Collini, Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Parma, V.le delle Scienze 181/A, 43100 Parma, Italy. Email: luca.collini@unipr.it

abstract.p: In this study, the authors present a micromechanical finite element modelling approach to the analysis of a set of ultrafine-grained polycrystalline copper structures. The models take into account both realistic grain distribution and the number of refinement passes of the microstructure. The grain size effect is successfully predicted, with non-uniform deformation and shear localization reproduced during global plastic flow in agreement with experimental observations. The models provide a useful tool with which to interpret damage and fracture mechanisms occurring in ultrafine-grained structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Ultrafine-grained (UFG) materials are characterized by arrangements and grain (sub-)structures below the micro-scale in size. In most cases, the mechanical characteristics of these new micro- and nanostructures are better than those seen in the original materials.1 UFG materials have many technological applications, but due to their outstanding mechanical properties they are particularly successfully employed in aircraft and high-performance tool construction.2

The highly localized shear strain imposed during the grain refinement process is employed to enhance UFG behaviour in two main ways.3 The first technique involves so-called ‘bottom-up’ synthesis, in which atoms, molecules and nanoparticles participate to build blocks in the creation of complex structures. The second includes ‘top-down’ processes in which hard solid-state elaboration of materials occurs. During the first approach, coarse-grained (CG) materials are refined into nanostructured materials through heavy straining or shock loading. The latter materials constitute the main interest of this article.

As UFG materials are currently in high market demand, researchers are under pressure to make a complete identification of UFG mechanical behaviour. At present, the most frequently studied UFG materials are magnesium, titanium, aluminium and copper alloys, the latter being the main focus here. UFG copper (UFG-Cu) is obtained from CG copper (CG-Cu), with the face-centred cubic (FCC) crystallographic system of the latter retained through the use of a variety of different techniques. The most popular of these are electro-deposition, mechanical alloying and severe plastic deformation (SPD) techniques. The final class includes the equal channel angular pressing (ECAP) method, which involves the cold refinement of the grain structure, obtained via repeated passage of a material billet through an angular die.4 As illustrated in Figure 1, the UFG-Cu obtained from an increasing number of SPD passages presents a structure composed of equi-axed grains, but of a medium size that is greatly reduced with respect to that of the original CG-Cu. The process can also increase material tensile strength four-fold, with no dramatic loss of ductility.5

sec.p: While the tensile response, fatigue resistance and fracture behaviour of UFG materials are well established, few studies have investigated the role played by their peculiar microstructure in stress and strain field evolution. In particular, in order for an appropriate and complete description of the advanced characteristics of UFG metals to be achieved, much work remains to be done in terms of the characterization of the underlying basic deformation mechanisms. Regarding the structure of the UFG-Cu, a number of relevant experimental studies investigating fatigue and fatigue crack resistance have been presented.1,6–14 Nevertheless, to the authors’ knowledge, a very limited amount of work has dealt with the development of models that interpret the mechanical response (e.g. tensile strength) of UFG materials throughout the various stages of the refinement process.15,16 Contributing to this body of work represents the main focus of this article, as well as the effective tests – which have already been carried out on real specimens12,13– from which many currently used UFG material parameters are derived. An extensive finite element analysis is also employed to underline and clarify the evolution mechanism of material stress and strain fields, with particular attention paid to the effect of grain size. Although the micromechanical model considered here refers to the material structure of copper, in both a CG state and three increasing UFG states, once the material parameters are known, the proposed modelling approach is applicable to any UFG metal.

sec.title: Mechanism of deformation in UFG structures
sec.p: UFG structures are characterized by a size effect derived from the intense refinement of their grains. In fact, this reduction in structure size also results in deformation mechanisms that are different from those of ordinary coarse structures. During the refinement process, the formation of a new type of high-density dislocation, known as geometrically necessary dislocation (GND), can cause a shift away from the Hall–Petch relation, which relates the ultimate strength of a metal to its grain size. As a consequence, deformation in the plastic regime does not appear uniform, while, and more significantly, the interaction between the new small grain interior (GI) and grain boundary (GB) regions assumes increasing importance, as the GB gradually becomes thicker and represents a stiff wall around each single grain. This characteristic mechanism can influence plastic flow involving the pile-up of dislocations.17

In order to analyse these structures more effectively, a number of new models have been developed during the last few years, including ‘core and mantle’ models,18 atomistic approaches,19 as well as theoretical studies applied to conventional case studies.20 The complexity of the mechanisms involved in the evolution of UFG structures certainly justifies the great number of different models developed to analyse particular characteristics; however, each of these models can be classified in terms of the scale they work at: at scales of down to about 1 µm, theories related to classical crystal plasticity theory based on the work of Asaro and Rice21 are appropriate; for smaller scales, one should rely on strain gradient crystal plasticity theories.22 Modelling material behaviour provides the possibility of optimizing its microstructure, for example, in terms of structural and technological parameters, towards the needs of a specific application. For example, the prediction of plastic accumulation during fatigue conditions is often crucial since the process can lead to the development of shear bands and the nucleation of cracks, as reported in numerous studies.23–26 Fatigue loading may also result in detrimental grain coarsening,9 which has stimulated much recent study of microstructural stabilization.

sec.title: Scale factor
sec.p: The modelling approach employed in this study is based on a real, bi-dimensional microstructural grain distribution, with the characteristic microstructural parameters, such as grain mean size, distribution and interior angles, calculated with reference to grain texture in order to reproduce a set of data with a ‘statistically equivalent’ structure. Several methods are available for such a purpose (e.g. Collini and Nicoletto,27 Nicoletto et al.28 and Collini29), but here we apply the tessellation technique based on the Voronoi algorithm,30 using a transmission electron microscope (TEM) micrograph of the UFG structure as a starting reference image (see Figure 2(a)). The result of the Voronoi tessellation is shown in Figure 2(b).

caption.p: (a) TEM image of UFG copper microstructure and (b) its reproduction via the tessellation technique.

sec.p: This replication process results in a microstructural field or ‘window’ that contains about 300 grains of different sizes and geometries. As already mentioned, the grain distribution is statistically equivalent to that of the original micrograph, since it shows the same parameters of grain size and standard deviation. In this way, a discrete microstructural model can be obtained, such as that displayed in Figure 3. This model, which corresponds to the area superimposed in Figure 2(b), represents a restricted area of the original texture chosen as the field of study.

caption.p: Micromechanical finite element model of the microstructural arrangement of grains.

sec.p: The model geometry can be classified into two distinct regions: one representing GBs and the other GIs. Since it deals with microstructures of different grain refinement level, an essential and novel feature of this article is the definition of a microstructural scale factor, with which one can vary the relative size of grains on the same reference bound. This can be done by artificially tuning the thickness of GBs. The basic principle behind the method is to treat the microstructure of a UFG metal as a two-phase ‘composite’, in which all GIs are considered as a ‘soft’ matrix and all GBs are viewed as the ‘hard’ reinforcement. A similar approach was previously adopted for an ideal, hexagonal texture.31 The experimental basis of this modelling approach is the fact that UFG metals are characterized by a very high density of high-angle non-equilibrium GBs and are also interface-controlled materials.2 Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the high-angle non-equilibrium GBs in UFG metals play a role similar to that of the reinforcement in metal matrix composites.

sec.p: The finite element models and their discretization were created using the commercial code ABAQUS. An automatic discretization process was chosen to generate the mesh, which contained around 4000 nodes and 3800 two-dimensional (2D) continuum elements. This mesh size was selected based on the previous work investigating the same problem, which indicated that reasonable convergence of results could be expected. Plane strain finite elements with quadratic formulation, reduced integration and hourglass control were chosen from the ABAQUS element library. Accordingly, three degrees of freedom (DOF) per node, u1, u2 and rotation, were employed.

sec.title: Boundary conditions
sec.p: In micromechanical simulation problems, a wide variety of boundary conditions (load and constraints) may be imposed. In this work, a set of links between the nodes at the boundaries was employed, in order to make the study window a self-periodic area. This modelling approach has previously proven itself to be a useful tool in studying the stress and strain fields of inhomogeneous materials at the microstructural level.29

sec.title: Model of constitutive law
sec.p: The aim of this work was to study micro-field evolution in a structure of varying grain size under tensile load. In order to achieve this, a material constitutive law was selected that takes into account the pre-strain condition given by SPD. An appropriate model for this task was defined by Lapovok et al.32 on the basis of previous work,33–35 with their formulation considering the evolution of dislocations in a severely plastically deformed metal, as well as the variation of gradient plasticity with changing microstructure. We therefore believe that this dislocation–evolution-based gradient plasticity model possesses a good predictive capability of describing the deformation behaviour of the UFG-Cu, which is itself a dislocation cell-forming material.24–26

Briefly, the model is based on a ‘phase mixture’ approach in which dislocation cell interiors and walls are treated as separate ‘phases’. In the formulation of the constitutive law, the deformation behaviour and intrinsic length scale parameter of the gradient plasticity model are related to microstructural characteristics, including dislocation cell size. The parameter α in equation (4) represents a numerical constant varying from 0.1 to 0.5. The GND- and SSD-related terms are described as a function of the cell wall volume fraction (f), cell wall thickness (φ) and, most importantly, of the cell wall and interior dislocation densities. The quantities entered into the model in the case of copper are obtained from Lapovok et al.32 Most of these quantities (K, M, N, A, B and C) are calculated using the expressions above or those reported in Appendix 1; others, such as dc and f, are determined experimentally via TEM observation.37

The process of deformation and the resultant distribution of stress and strain are almost qualitatively described by the model, thanks to the factors involved in equation (4). In fact, the model also takes into account a length scale parameter (l) that depends on both (i) material structure constants (M, α and b) and (ii) factors characterizing the SPD (µ and σ0).

The material constitutive law was implemented in tabular form via ABAQUS using data points calculated by the model. An elasto-plastic, strain-gradient crystal plasticity law was assumed for both GI and GB regions of the UFG structures under examination; this formulation has the advantage of intrinsically taking into account the formation of dislocations and, consequently, the reinforcement mechanism, which is macroscopically expressed by the plastic flow. In contrast, the unrefined CG state is modelled using a classical Ramberg–Osgood law,38 respecting the parameters of yield stress, Young’s modulus and plastic strain hardening of an as-annealed alloy.14

sec.title: Tensile behaviour
sec.p: The finite element models were validated by comparing the results of simulations with the experimental data, in predicting the response of the UFG-Cu to uniaxial tension.

The tensile stress–strain behaviour of the considered structures is shown in Figure 5; stress and strain were calculated as macroscopic quantities, see equation (3). The solid and dashed lines in Figure 5 represent the simulated σM−εM relationships up to a strain level of 3.3%, and the symbols indicate experimental points.5,37

caption.p: Simulated (lines) and experimental (symbols) tensile response of CG and UFG microstructures.
ECAP: equal channel angular pressing.

sec.p: As can be seen from Figure 5, although the models are in 2D formulation, they were able to correctly reproduce the macroscopic tensile response of Cu microstructures in the development of the yield and in the early hardening regime. This is not surprising if one considers that unless a necking of the tensile specimen occurs, the stress state is essentially one-dimensional. In fact, usually for ductile materials, a circular specimen can show necking of its cross section at macroscopic strains much higher than that considered here.

The 8-ECAP Cu curve identifies the latter microstructure to be of higher strength. This is in accordance with experimental evidence revealing that after more than 10 ECAP passes the dislocation-based mechanism of reinforcement is less important than structural rearrangement, resulting in a lower yielding stress. The curves also reproduce the shift away from the Hall–Petch relationship that is typical of UFG metals, as previously described elsewhere.17,18

sec.title: Evolution of stress and strain fields
sec.p: The unique stress and strain fields in the copper microstructures were derived from the simulated tensile load reported in Figure 5. Different behaviours are apparent for each microstructure, depending on the grain refinement and constitutive law for the GB and GI areas. As already shown in Figure 5, the models are loaded so that the macroscopic tensile stress exceeds the uniaxial yield stress; in this way, the plastic flow process can be reproduced.

The stress fields will now be discussed in terms of the equivalent Von Mises stress in order to consider all stress contributions to the plastic regime. The distributions of stress derived from a longitudinal strain of 3% are shown in Figure 6. The simulated data contain two interesting aspects. The first is that peak values of stress are localized in the GB regions (not shown in the contours for clarity), as a result of the higher stiffness of GBs relative to GI areas, particularly at the junctions. This stress distribution inside and across the grains is plotted in Figure 7, with the line A–B indicating the path along which the stresses were computed. As can be seen from Figure 7, stresses in the GI regions are more uniform, with the exception of some local relaxation due to redistribution near the GB intersections. However, the stress value internal of the grains oscillates within the range of 15–25 MPa. These results are in agreement with the experimental findings.17

ECAP: equal channel angular pressing.

sec.p: The second significant result is that at the same macroscopic strain level, ideal stresses are higher in the structure associated with an intermediate level of refinement, that is, eight ECAP passes, indicating that this structure resolves the load in a higher and more uniform stress micro-field. Indeed, the models predict that stress field perturbation increases with stages of grain refinement, thus revealing a significant role of grain size distribution in the organization of intra-grain deformation. In real microstructures, the gliding of small dislocation groups in the largest grains is initiated at yield stress. Simultaneously, sliding along their boundaries takes place, with further deformation provided by intra-grain gliding and GB sliding of smaller grains.

The four pictures shown in Figure 6 also reveal the onset of a series of stress concentration bands at a near 45° angle to load direction. Stress and/or strain localization represents the spontaneous development of coexisting flowing and stationary regions in a sheared metal and has been identified and studied experimentally in a huge variety of ductile materials. Shear banding may play an important role in metal failure modes, since localization is a precursor to fracture in bulk metals and has generally been cited as a mechanism for material weakening. In the refined microstructures observed in this study, localization bands appeared despite the scale effect that was introduced by thickening the GBs. However, localization in bands was somewhat weakened in 10- and 12-pass structures, revealing that load transfer from grain to grain is more difficult in such structures and thus leads to increasing inhomogeneity.

The UFG structures typically evolve during deformation derived from the influence of crystal plane sliding and dislocation mechanisms.39 This hardening of the UFG structures results in the material being able to resist higher magnitudes of stress and to adopt different stress and strain distributions in individual grains. The numerical results obtained here corroborate this mechanism, with stress concentrations in larger grains promoting plastic deformation of less-stressed grains.

Further investigation was conducted by arranging the distribution of stresses in the four microstructures using a statistical approach aimed at analysing the quantitative effect of grain refinement on stress distribution. Statistical distribution curves were derived from the finite element analysis output and plotted in Weibull probability paper, with the results reported in Figure 8.

caption.p: Statistical distribution of equivalent stress in the CG and UFG structures at 3% strain plotted in Weibull probability paper.
CG: coarse-grained; ECAP: equal channel angular pressing.

sec.p: After plotting the probability function of the equivalent stress at 3% plastic strain, it can be seen that the 12-ECAP Cu had the highest dispersion (corresponding to a heterogeneous distribution of stress intensity), whereas the 8-ECAP Cu showed a more homogeneous stress field.

Figure 9 presents the results of strain field analysis, with the contours depicting the distribution of the principal plastic strain. The analysis of these colour maps and the plot of strain quantity (Figure 10) along the same path A–B clearly reveals that the CG-Cu sample experienced the highest uniformity of plastic deformation, while instead the UFG state was characterized by higher peak values. This result is in agreement with the experimental findings showing that a dislocation emitted in smaller grains leads to lower plastic deformation than that observed in larger grains.39 Statistical distributions extrapolated for plastic strain plotted in Weibull probability paper (see Figure 11) reveal that regularity of the strain field decreases as the grain mean size decreases, with the best arrangement reached in the 8-ECAP structure, as showed by the shape parameter m. sec.p: where the numerator difference is the range of the equivalent plastic strain and εM is the imposed far-field strain; in other words, values of this index indicate the inhomogeneity of plastic strain distribution. The values of iPE, that is, 0.53 for CG, 0.47 for 8-ECAP, 0.73 for 10-ECAP and 1.5 for the 12-ECAP structure, clearly demonstrates that 8-ECAP refinement resulted in the most uniformly distributed strain, with increasing numbers of refinement passes producing higher peaks and greater variability.

This finding confirms that the stiff GBs that characterize the UFG structures are able to pose considerably more resistance to overall plastic deformation; as a result, strain accommodation is prevented and the structure accumulates peaks of plastic deformation, leading to a non-uniform distribution. Whereas equivalent stress becomes concentrated in the GBs, in GI regions it assumes a nearly constant value; in contrast, the pattern observed in terms of the plastic strain field differs, with the latter being heterogeneous inside the GIs due to the deformation mechanism.

sec.title: Interpretation of the damage initiation mechanism
sec.p: The data presented in Figure 12, an experimental image of shear band formation in the UFG-Cu microstructure, are in good agreement with the strain maps shown in Figure 9. A number of recent studies have reported that shear band development and orientation have a strong influence on the formation and propagation of micro-defects and cracks,25 while the dependence of dislocation nucleation on the direction of the sliding plane defined by the last ECAP pass has also been observed in the UFG-Cu structures.40 Significantly, experimental investigation has revealed that dislocations nucleate parallel to the direction of this particular sliding plane and, as a result, when dislocations accumulate and shear band formation begins, the initial micro-cracks contained in the slip band protrusions also evolve in this direction. Thus, at least initially, micro-crack development follows the direction of plastic strain accumulation and shear band formation; later, as the deformation evolves and the plastic strain zone increases in area, defects progressively acquire a larger amount of energy and eventually change their paths.

caption.p: Strain distribution and shear band formation in UFG copper at: (a) 100, (b) 150 and (c) 200 Mpa; undeformed zones are indicated by the letter U.26

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This work presents a micromechanical modelling approach containing two main novel elements in the simulation of the mechanical behaviour of UFG structures: (i) the reproduction of an in-plane, polycrystalline grain distribution, which permits the analysis of internal stress and strain field evolution under tensile (and eventually shear) load; and (ii) a geometrical scale factor that allows the reproduction of various grain refinements with respect to an initial grain texture.

The models were able to consistently reproduce stress distributions experimentally observed occurring in the GI and across the GBs of the UFG-Cu, hence confirming their applicability to UFG metals. The models also demonstrated, independent of grain size, that over the macroscopic yield stress range, the GBs carry higher stresses (10%–20% greater) than interiors, depending on the level of structural refinement. Grain size distribution was found to play a significant role in the organization of intra-grain deformation; grains of different sizes make different contributions to deformation, since minimum strain variability was observed in the highest-strength microstructure, increasing with any further grain refinement. The developed modelling approach was also able to reproduce shear band formation (and evolution) at yield load in accordance with experimental observation.
